Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Mechanisms of feeding behavior regulation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Animals regulate the quality and quantity of their food intake to maintain nutrient homeostasis. Although studies on regulation of feeding behavior have focused on central feedback mechanisms that control appetite, some evidence suggests that peripheral sensory activity is modulated under certain conditions. That such modulation can be specific - carbohydrate deprivation causes increased sensitivity to sugars and protein deprivation causes increased sensitivity to amino acids - argues for the existence of mechanisms that target the activity of receptors or cells that recognize specific categories of taste chemicals. In insects, the levels of macronutrients in the hemolymph are known to sway the responsiveness of taste neurons, however the molecular mechanisms by which this occurs are poorly understood. This project investigates the hypothesis that members of a large, divergent family of Gustatory receptor (Gr) genes are regulatory targets of pathways that operate to sense internal nutritional needs. In addition, genome-wide approaches will be applied to identify novel genes that are differentially regulated by changes in nutrient demand. These studies will determine the importance of Gr regulation under different physiological conditions and establish a foundation for inquiry into the molecular underpinnings of compensatory food selection and intake.

The proposed studies will generate broader impact through an educational plan that provides hands-on research experience to several early-career undergraduate students from under-represented groups through a summer research program. The project will also provide training for a graduate student and a postdoctoral scientist. Each year two undergraduate students will be selected to participate in a follow-up research training program during which time they will engage in genetic screens to identify loci involved in regulating feeding behaviors. All participants will engage in near-peer mentoring and annual assessment will be used to develop effective ways with which to integrate research training with science education and career guidance. The data generated from this project will be made available through scientific publications and deposition in public databases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major research goals of our project were to characterize dietary macronutrient imbalance-induced changes in taste sensitivity, and to identify candidate genes and signaling pathways that operate to bring out these changes. We used the model insect, Drosophila melanogaster, to carry out our studies using a multidisciplinary approach spanning genetics, global analyses of gene expression, recordings of taste neuron activity, and suites of behavior assays to evaluate taste sensitivity and food choice in flies that were given diets with varying quantities of carbohydrate and protein. We found that dietary sugar-protein imbalance independently altered behavioral preference for sugars and amino acids. A significant finding from our studies is that changes in sugar preference occurred via a direct impact on sweet taste, whose alteration depended on two different signaling pathways (dopamine and insulin-like peptide 5) that acted in response to too much or too little sugar in the diet. Together, our studies linked diet to taste sensitivity to switches in food preference that may compensate for macronutrient imbalance in food sources. We followed up on our initial findings by identifying critical functions for taste neurons present in the pharynx for food selection, and by characterizing global changes in gene expression in the brain and in taste sensory organs upon exposure to dietary sugar-protein imbalance.  Finally, we investigated taste receptors as possible targets of pathways that signaled dietary sugar-protein imbalance, identifying in the process a novel role for a highly conserved ionotropic receptor, Ir76b, in sensing amino acids. Our exciting findings establish a foundation for uncovering fundamental molecular and cellular mechanisms that link diet to alterations in taste sensitivity and changes in food selection, which may also have implications for modification of food choice in insect pests and vectors.

We accomplished our research objectives in conjunction with research training and science education of undergraduate students via a summer research program. Through the summer program we provided research opportunities to 24 early career undergraduate students; ten students continued research in the laboratory. Graduate students or postdoctoral researchers who were supported by this project mentored three additional undergraduate students. The summer program offered undergraduate students opportunities to get research training, but also to serve as research instructors and mentors in following years, and we have been implementing assessment tools to evaluate the success of the program and its impact on the participants. So far, we published two research articles with undergraduate authors and one more will follow. Project personnel were also involved in local outreach events each year - Brain Day at UC Riverside and the Riverside Annual Insect Fair - with an educational booth aimed at bringing the excitement of neurobiology research and an understanding of the value of genetic model systems to the general public.
